title: 111_hr3375
content: The Act titled "Stop White-collar Assistance to Terrorists Act" introduces amendments to address credit card fraud and financial fraud, imposing stricter penalties for offenses related to terrorism. For terrorism-related offenses, the maximum term of imprisonment is increased to 20 years for first-time convictions and 30 years for repeat offenses under Section 1029 (c) of title 18, United States Code. The Act "Stop White-collar Assistance to Terrorists Act" increases penalties for terrorism-related offenses, with maximum imprisonment terms of 25 years for counterfeit securities, 20 years for unlicensed money transmitting businesses, and additional provisions for money laundering. The Act "Stop White-collar Assistance to Terrorists Act" increases penalties for terrorism-related offenses, with maximum imprisonment terms of 30 years for bribery committed to facilitate acts of domestic or international terrorism. The maximum term of imprisonment for acts of domestic or international terrorism under the Social Security Fraud section is increased to 20 years. SEC. 4. PROVIDING MATERIAL SUPPORT TO TERRORISTS. Section 2339A of title 18, United States Code, is amended by increasing the maximum term of imprisonment from "15 years" to "30 years". SEC. 5. AMENDMENT TO THE SENTENCING GUIDELINES RELATING TO CERTAIN CRIMES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for terrorism-related offenses to increase penalties, in line with Congress' intent. The guidelines and policy statements emphasize the seriousness of offenses and the need for effective deterrents. They consider factors like harm to the public, level of planning, and threat to public health or safety. Consistency with other directives and sentencing guidelines is also ensured. The sentencing guidelines and policy statements consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances and aim to meet the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law.
